pullRequest.body:
This is taken from [my zulip message here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/How.20to.20simplify.20this.20proof.20without.20using.20a.20have.20statement.3F/near/422294189).

As an example:
```lean
example : 2^10 = eval% 2^10 := by
  -- goal is `2^10 = 1024`
  sorry
```

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Is this expected to work with let-bound vars? e.g. 
```lean
example : True := let a := 2; let b := eval% a * 2
```

At the moment we get some horrible fvar error: `(kernel) declaration has free variables '_tmp._@.Mathlib._hyg.174'`
That's not expected to work; though it could certainly give a better message. You could always put the `let` inside the `eval%`

:v: eric-wieser can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

For a future version, it would be nice if it could capture local `let` values.

One way to implement this: figure out which variables would need to be reverted, throw an error if any of them are not `let`s, and then use `mkLetFVars` before passing it to eval.

bors merge


Perhaps worth noting that this won't handle universe variables correctly until https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/pull/3090 lands.

Build failed:
  * Build
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8270846792/job/22629315913)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8270846792/job/22629315088)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8270846792/job/22629315405)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion let ee Elab.Term.elabTerm ( `(Lean.toExpr $( e.toSyntax))) (some q(Expr)) ```
This would be a lot cleaner with #5952, but that PR is not ready to merge yet, and this is just a test file anyway.

```suggestion
/-- `Finset ` can be converted to an expr only if there is some way to find `DecidableEq `. -/
```

```suggestion
@[term_elab eval_expr, inherit_doc eval_expr]
```
maybe?
Sure, can't hurt.

```suggestion

The `!`-version `eval%! x` also logs the expression computed by `eval%`.
-/
syntax (name := eval_expr) "eval% " ("!")? term : term

/-- An auxilliary function for converting Syntax to an `Expr`. -/
unsafe def elabEvalExprCore (stx: TSyntax `term) (exp: Option Expr) : TermElabM Expr := do
  let e  Lean.Elab.Term.elabTermAndSynthesize stx exp
  let e  instantiateMVars e
  let ee  Elab.Term.elabTerm ( `(Lean.toExpr $( e.toSyntax))) (some q(Expr))
  Lean.Meta.evalExpr Expr q(Expr) ee (safety := .unsafe)

@[term_elab eval_expr, inherit_doc eval_expr]
unsafe def elabEvalExpr : Lean.Elab.Term.TermElab
| `(term| eval% $stx) => elabEvalExprCore stx
| `(term| eval%! $stx) => fun exp => do
  let res  elabEvalExprCore stx exp
  logInfo m!"'eval% {stx}' computed '{ Meta.ppExpr res}'"
  return res
```
What do you think of this?  This way, if you use `eval%` and it does not work, you have the option of seeing what it is that it computed.

For instance, you would get some indication of what failed here:
```lean
#guard_expr
  (eval%! Finset.powerset ({1, 2, 3})) =
    {{1}, {2}, {1, 2}, {3}, {1, 3}, {2, 3}, {1, 2, 3}}
/-
`guard` says the result is not true, but `eval%` says

'eval% Finset.powerset ({1, 2, 3})' computed '{, {1}, {2}, {1, 2}, {3}, {1, 3}, {2, 3}, {1, 2, 3}}'
-/
```
Isn't this just combining `eval%` with `show_term`?
You are probably right, but then maybe it might be useful to mention this in the doc-string, since I had not thought of using `show_term` in this situation.

```suggestion

Using 'show_term eval% x' displays what is the value of 'eval% x'.
-/
```
Do you think that this might be useful?

How about phrased like this?

```suggestion

Tip: you can use `show_term eval% x` to see the value of `eval% x`.
-/
```

Let's go ahead with including `eval%`:

bors d+
Added, but I replaced `get` with `see` to avoid any confusion about how to store the gotten value.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add an `eval%` elaborator for interpolating the output of `#eval`
